tweets.text: In an effort to bring more of my thoughts out to Twitterland, I’m taking on @vgr’s one tweet/opinion/hot take per like. Given that I don’t have a whole lot of followers, I may just spit some hot takes regardless. https://t.co/y8IlBLbOg7

Recently came back from a trip to India. Given all the dietary changes I’ve made for myself over the last year (intermittent fasting, low carb, more protein and healthy fats) it was a bit jarring to see how difficult it was  to maintain that over there.
I actually lost weight on that trip. For those not in the know that is a challenging thing to do because everyone will try to feed you endlessly when you visit.
So. Many. Carbs. I couldn’t do it.
Snacking is endemic. Combo of 5 or 6 different things, usually a mix of nuts or some sort of processed fried carb snack/crackers/biscuit. It’s just designed to make you overeat.
Sugar everywhere too. Indian sweets are essentially concentrated diabetes.

Speaking of which, there are some studies showing that Indians are at higher risk of diabetes and heart disease. Supposedly could be a genetic thing but my gut tells me the diet may play a bigger role.

And fun fact I learned on that trip, there’s a beef ban in India now. Granted beef wasn’t super widely available (at least as far as I could tell), but was surprising to hear they outright banned consumption. Apparently it’s still cool to export it though.
Fairly certain it’s political BS anyhow. If they banned chicken the whole country would probably riot.
Although no beef, buffalo meat is readily available there. Went to a Korean restaurant outside of New Delhi that served buffalo kalbi. Super delicious.
I will say though, for all the deficiencies in the Indian diet/eating habits, homemade Indian food in India is great. So much so that I can’t really enjoy Indian food back here in the US.

Some dude a few weeks back caused some controversy for saying something along the lines of Indian food is terrible. In the context of Indian food in the US, I tend to agree.  At least for North Indian/Punjabi food.
Word to the wise: Avoid the buffets.
Personally I prefer going to a Pakistani restaurant if I want Punjabi food.

South Indian food in the US tends to be on point though. Granted I probably don’t have the same level of discernment for South Indian food as North Indian food so maybe take that with a grain of salt.

Another fun fact: you can do tandoori chicken sans the tandoor in the comforts of your own home. Just need a slow cooker, whole chicken, tandoori paste, and yogurt and you’re all set. https://t.co/Nhtg6JxZS7
I’m out of takes for this topic at the moment, may have more later but for now I’m gonna dive into that aforementioned tandoori chicken.
Getting more likes than I was expecting for this, let’s see how much more I can add to this thread

I saw earlier on my timeline something about turmeric lattes being controversial due to cultural appropriation? Personally I think haldi ka doodh (turmeric milk) is kinda gross, but if you’re really feeling up for it sure, appropriate to your heart’s content.

Also something I’ve been wondering for some time is that Indian food tends tends to be differentiated between North Indian and South Indian, however I never hear anything regarding food in eastern India (Sikkim, Assam, Manipur, etc).
Not sure if it’s possible in the US to even get any food from that region of India, gonna have to research further. If anyone does happen to know of such a place please do let me know.
